awd_titl_txt: CHS:  Small:   A Perceptual-based Approach to improve Synthetic Crowds
awd_abstract_narration:
In principle, crowd simulations could help designers make buildings both nicer and safer by allowing them to explore how people would move through the building in both normal and emergency situations.  However, it is unclear whether existing tools for simulating crowds reflect the motion of actual people, which makes designers hesitant to use them.  This project's goal is to develop a method that allows people to visually compare the realism of computer-generated crowd movement to real crowd movement.  The idea is that the more a simulated crowd looks as real as an actual crowd, then the more likely that the algorithm used to generate the simulation and the simulation itself will be useful in building design and will be trusted by building designers.  The team will address these questions by (1) processing videos of real crowd motion in buildings to generate 3D reconstructions, then (2) asking both non-experts and facilities managers to (a) rate the realism of parallel videos that use the real crowd paths versus simulated crowd paths through the reconstructed building and (b) comment on aspects of the videos that affect their ratings.  These data will be useful for both evaluating and improving the quality of future crowd simulation algorithms; to this end, the team will release the videos, datasets, algorithms, experimental tools, and results to help other researchers in this and related areas.  They will also use the materials in college courses aimed at simulation and modeling, as well as developing outreach experiences for middle and high school students and outreach materials for building designers.

To generate the experimental materials, the team will first process crowd videos drawn from existing crowd movement video databases when possible and captured by the team when needed to represent conditions not available in those databases.  They will then extract people's initial locations and paths, using Catmull-Rom splines to compensate for noise in the extraction of location and building features and variations in frame rates between videos, as well as creating a 3D reconstruction of the facility.  For generating simulated paths, they will use the captured starting location, time, and ending location as input to a suite of open source agent-steering algorithms that represent a wide variety of simulation approaches.  To remove visual cues from the original films that might influence judgments, both the original paths and the simulated paths will be generated using the Unity 3D graphics rendering and physics engine, which is commonly used in crowd simulation research.  Finally, the team will develop an interface for rating and annotating pairs of videos (and, for longer videos, video segments) for realism.  This interface will be used in the experiments described above in which participants compare real and simulated renderings, as well as comparisons between different segments of the same video, to collect as wide a variety of data as possible on factors that affect realism judgments.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Computers can simulate the motion of people in a group. If these crowd simulations are accurate, they can predict the behavior of people in day-to-day and emergency situations. Unfortunately, crowd simulations do now always reflect how people move in real life. To improve crowd simulation accuracy, we created a new method for evaluating the realism of simulated crowds. While being shown crowd simulations side-by-side with film of real crowds, people were asked to select the crowd that looked more like a real crowd. Doing these crowd-sourced comparisons allowed us to determine how realistic current crowd simulations are in comparison to filmed crowds. It also allowed us to improve crowd simulations so they would be more accurate.

The results of this project included contributions to the scientific body of knowledge, improving the safety of public spaces (specifically medical facilities), and providing educational opportunities for underrepresented populations.

This project contributed to the scientific body of knowledge with its academic publications. These publications allowed other researchers and public infrastructure owners to learn about the results of this project.

This project contributed to the safety of public safety by identifying crowd simulations that were more realistic than others. Using these more realistic simulations, the owners and managers of public spaces can predict with more accuracy how people behave in their space. Specifically, this project worked directly with medical experts to improve medical facilities and educate medical workers, in the emergency department domain and mass triage domain, respectively.

This project improved our understanding of how medical professionals and patients move through an emergency department. By partnering with the University of Nebraska Medical Center, we were able to create a 3D model of an emergency department. Then, together with doctors and nurses from this emergency department, we created behaviors for the different medical staff, residents, and patients that use an emergency room facility.

Similarly, we partnered with the University of Nebraska Medical Center Department of Nursing to create a simulation of a hospital after a natural disaster. In this specific case, we created a simulation of a hospital after being hit by a tornado. In this kind of mass-casualty situation, medical professionals need to quickly triage survivors to prioritize medical support. The nursing faculty at the University of Nebraska Medical Center have been training nursing students in mass casualty triage for many years but wanted to move past in-class instruction. Together with these nursing faculty, we created this hospital simulation. Using a VR headset or a laptop, students were able to practice what they had learned in class in a computer simulation. This reinforced what they had learned, taught them new skills, and better prepared them for mass causality situations they may face.

Lastly, this project provided educational opportunities for underrepresented populations. The funds in this grant helped fund outreach opportunities at the University of Nebraska at Omaha, including the CodeCrush, Techademy, and High School Internship programs. The primary investigator also participated directly in many of these programs.

 


Last Modified: 02/08/2022
Modified by: Brian C Ricks
